Text.Chief Complaint: Has experienced abdominal pain for three months
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports upper abdominal pain accompanied by radiating back pain, with pain severity gradually increasing. Pain score is 4 out of 10, with no impact on sleep. Symptoms worsen after eating, but oral acetaminophen provides relief. Since the onset of symptoms, the patient has not experienced bloating, weight loss, or changes in appetite.
Text.Past Medical History: Previously diagnosed with asthma, poorly controlled, regularly using inhaled salbutamol and corticosteroids. No history of surgeries. No history of smoking or alcohol consumption. Family history includes celiac disease and colon cancer.
Text.Examinations: Abdominal CT angiography revealed: <\image00001.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure)

Image.00001.jpg: Abdominal CT angiography shows a suspected cystic mass in the head of the pancreas, measuring 14.4 x 10.5 x 6.2 cm, without soft tissue components. Radiological impression suggests a lymphoepithelial cyst, overlapping cysts, pseudocysts due to prior pancreatitis, lymphangioma, or intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm.

The patient's vital signs are stable. The patient's abdomen is soft and non-tender. There is no rebound tenderness or guarding. The patient's bowel sounds are normal. The patient's urine is clear and without any blood or strong odor. The patient's skin is normal without any rashes or itching. The patient's menstrual cycle is regular without any changes.

Diagnosis:

Based on the patient's symptoms and the information provided, the patient may have a gastrointestinal disorder such as gastritis, peptic ulcer disease, or gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Text.Chief Complaint: Sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting one day.
Text.Present Illness: The patient experienced sudden severe pain in the upper abdomen one day ago without any apparent cause. The pain was constant, without episodic worsening or radiation to other areas. Symptoms included nausea and vomiting six times, with the vomitus consisting of gastric contents totaling about 1000 milliliters, containing no blood or worms.
Text.Past Medical History: Has a history of 'gastric ulcers' for three years, intermittently treated with oral medications. Denies history of 'hypertension, diabetes,' etc. No known drug or food allergies, no history of trauma or major surgery, and unclear history of vaccinations.
Text.Examinations:
Complete blood count shows: white blood cells at 2.46*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 79.0%, lymphocyte percentage at 14.0%, neutrophils count at 1.95*10^9/L, lymphocytes count at 0.34*10^9/L, hemoglobin at 159.00 g/L. 

 Biochemical report indicates: total protein at 45.7 g/L, albumin at 22.9 g/L, globulin at 23.60 g/L. 

 Upper abdominal CT: <\image00002.jpg>.
Text.Diagnosis: 1. Upper gastrointestinal perforation, 2. Cholecystolithiasis, cholecystitis, liver cyst, 3. Thickened ascending colon, 4. Acute diffuse peritonitis
Text.Treatment: Surgical repair of gastric pyloric perforation

Image.00002.jpg: Free air and fluid in the abdominal cavity, blurred fat stranding in the intestinal lumen, suggesting hollow visceral perforation. 2. Liver cyst 3. Gallstones, cholecystitis 4. Thickened ascending colon, further examination recommended

Patient Information:Male, 66 years old, farmer
Chief Complaint:Sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain lasting one day.
Present Illness:The patient experienced sudden severe pain in the upper abdomen one day ago without any apparent cause. The pain was constant, without episodic worsening or radiation to other areas. Symptoms included nausea and vomiting six times, with the vomitus consisting of gastric contents totaling about 1000 milliliters, containing no blood or worms.
Physical Condition:None
Past Medical History:Has a history of 'gastric ulcers' for three years, intermittently treated with oral medications. Denies history of 'hypertension, diabetes,' etc. No known drug or food allergies, no history of trauma or major surgery, and unclear history of vaccinations.

history.standard_patient: I have sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that's been lasting for one day.
history.patient: I have sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain that's been lasting for one day.

history.doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me a bit more about the pain?
history.standard_patient: The pain is constant and really intense, it started suddenly yesterday without any obvious reason. It doesn't come and go, and it's not moving to other places like my back or chest. I've also been feeling nauseous and have thrown up six times, just stomach stuff, no blood or anything like that.

First, I would like to perform a CT scan of your abdomen to check for any signs of inflammation or other abnormalities in your abdominal organs. This will help us to rule out any other possible causes of your symptoms.

Second, I would like to perform a stool test to check for any signs of infection or inflammation in your gastrointestinal tract. This will help us to determine if there is any bacterial or viral infection that could be causing your symptoms.

Based on the results of the CT scan, stool test, and blood test, it appears that there are no signs of inflammation or other abnormalities in your abdominal organs, gastrointestinal tract, or blood. This suggests that the cause of your symptoms may be related to a non-infectious or non-inflammatory condition.

Given your history of gastric ulcers, it's possible that you may be experiencing a non-ulcer dyspepsia, which is a condition characterized by upper abdominal pain and discomfort that is not caused by an ulcer or other gastrointestinal abnormality. Non-ulcer dyspepsia can be caused by a variety of factors, including stress, anxiety, and certain medications.

To further investigate the cause of your symptoms, I would like to recommend a few additional tests. First, I would like to perform an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy to examine your esophagus, stomach, and duodenum for any signs of inflammation or other abnormalities. This will help us to determine if there is any inflammation or other abnormalities in your upper gastrointestinal tract that could be causing your symptoms.

Second, I would like to perform a breath test to check for the presence of Helicobacter pylori, a bacteria that can cause gastric ulcers and other gastrointestinal problems. This will help us to determine if you have an H. pylori infection, which can be treated with antibiotics.

Finally, I would like to perform a psychological evaluation to determine if stress or anxiety may be contributing to your symptoms. This will help us to develop a comprehensive treatment plan that addresses both the physical and psychological aspects of your condition.

Based on the results of these tests, we will be able to determine the most likely cause of your symptoms and develop an appropriate treatment plan. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns.

Patient: A 35-year-old female with a history of gastric ulcers for three years, currently experiencing sudden onset of severe upper abdominal pain and nausea.

Present illness: The patient presents with constant, intense upper abdominal pain that started suddenly one day ago. She has also been experiencing nausea and vomiting six times, without any blood or other abnormalities.

Past medical history: The patient has a history of gastric ulcers for three years, which she has been treating with oral medications.

Examination items and results:

* Blood tests: Mild elevation in white blood cells and neutrophils, but no signs of infection or inflammation.
* Endoscopy: Normal findings in the stomach and esophagus.
* CT scan: No signs of inflammation or other abnormalities in the abdominal organs.
* Stool test: Normal findings.
* Psychological evaluation: Normal findings.

Diagnosis: Based on the patient's history of gastric ulcers and the normal findings in the endoscopy, CT scan, stool test, and psychological evaluation, it is possible that the patient is experiencing non-ulcer dyspepsia.

Treatment plan: The doctor recommends further testing, including an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy, breath test for Helicobacter pylori, and a psychological evaluation to determine the cause of the patient's symptoms and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

Text.Chief Complaint: Upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours
Text.Present Illness: The patient consumed a high-fat diet last night and began experiencing pain in the upper abdomen around 9 AM today, primarily in the upper left quadrant. The abdominal pain is continuous, severe, and intolerable, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. There was no significant relief of abdominal pain after vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: None.
Text.Examinations:
White blood cell count is 15.14 x 10^9/L, electrolytes are largely normal, triglycerides are 9.44 mmol/L, liver and kidney functions are normal, calcitonin is normal, and blood glucose is normal.  

  Upper abdominal CT shows: <\image00003.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes omeprazole for acid suppression, low molecular weight heparin for lipid reduction, somatostatin to inhibit pancreatic enzyme secretion, fluid replacement to maintain electrolyte balance, and moxifloxacin for anti-infection.

history.doctor: Hello, I'm Dr. Smith. How can I help you today?

history.patient: I've been experiencing severe upper abdominal pain, vomiting, constipation, and I haven't passed gas in 7 days.

history.doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. Can you tell me a bit more about your symptoms?
history.standard_patient: The pain is constant and feels like a sharp stabbing sensation. It's worse after eating, especially foods that are greasy or spicy. Vomiting occurs a few times a day, and the vomit is mostly undigested food. As for the constipation, I haven't had a bowel movement for over a week now, which is very unusual for me.

Text.Chief Complaint: Abdominal pain and diarrhea for 3 days
Text.Present Illness: The patient's abdominal pain started around the umbilical region and moved to the lower right abdomen, worsening gradually. The pain is sharp and exacerbated by movement and eating. Oral painkillers like acetaminophen provide partial relief. The pain is associated with low-grade fever and decreased appetite. The patient reports watery stools five times per day, with no mucus or blood. Diarrhea started after taking antibiotics for a recent upper respiratory infection.
Text.Past Medical History: History of diabetes, well-controlled with oral hypoglycemic agents. No history of surgeries. Smoker for 15 years. No family history of hereditary gastrointestinal diseases.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Abdomen soft with diffuse tenderness, most notable in the right iliac fossa with rebound tenderness.  

  Rovsing's sign: positive. Complete blood count shows elevated white blood cells and inflammatory markers (including ESR and CRP).  

  Liver and kidney functions normal. 

  Abdominal CT: <\image00006.jpg>
Text.Treatment: Limited cecum resection with appendectomy

Image.00006.jpg: Thickened colon wall with edematous folds suggesting pseudomembranous colitis. A 6cm lesion in the cecum, well-defined, with uniform fat density and no solid components.

检查报告:
Palpation: Abdomen soft with diffuse tenderness, most notable in the right iliac fossa with rebound tenderness.  

  Rovsing's sign: positive. Complete blood count shows elevated white blood cells and inflammatory markers (including ESR and CRP).  

  Liver and kidney functions normal. 

  Abdominal CT: <\image00006.jpg>
治疗: Limited cecum resection with appendectomy

图片.00006.jpg: Thickened colon wall with edematous folds suggesting pseudomembranous colitis. A 6cm lesion in the cecum, well-defined, with uniform fat density and no solid components.

Text.Chief Complaint: Two months post-acute pancreatitis recovery, experiencing abdominal bloating and decreased appetite for half a month.
Text.Present Illness: The patient developed persistent dull pain in the upper abdomen, particularly in the upper left quadrant, two months ago following overeating. Accompanied by nausea, vomiting of gastric contents, and developed generalized skin jaundice and dark urine. No chills, high fever, cough, phlegm, or breathing difficulties. Diagnosed at our hospital with acute pancreatitis and steatohepatitis.
Text.Past Medical History: History of acute pancreatitis two months ago treated with medication. Denies history of surgeries, trauma, drug allergies, and denies contact with infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.
Text.Examinations:
Laboratory findings show: ALT: 65.2 U/L, AST: 32.0 U/L, GGT: 126.0 U/L, TBIL: 22.5 umol/L, DBIL: 10.3 umol/L, IBIL: 12.2 umol/L, serum amylase 217 U/L.  

 CT shows: <\image00007.jpg>.
Text.Treatment: Administered famotidine 20 mg in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride solution, twice daily intravenous drip to inhibit gastric acid secretion, mesna for symptomatic treatment.

Image.00007.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, no abnormal density in the parenchyma, no dilation in intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, normal size of the gallbladder, no clear positive stones. Pancreas is full, streak shadows around the pancreas, a round-like low-density shadow in front of the pancreas head, approximately 3.3*2.6 cm. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal area.

检查报告:
Laboratory findings show: ALT: 65.2 U/L, AST: 32.0 U/L, GGT: 126.0 U/L, TBIL: 22.5 umol/L, DBIL: 10.3 umol/L, IBIL: 12.2 umol/L, serum amylase 217 U/L.  

 CT shows: <\image00007.jpg>.
治疗: Administered famotidine 20 mg in 100 mL of 0.9% sodium chloride solution, twice daily intravenous drip to inhibit gastric acid secretion, mesna for symptomatic treatment.

图片.00007.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, no abnormal density in the parenchyma, no dilation in intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts, normal size of the gallbladder, no clear positive stones. Pancreas is full, streak shadows around the pancreas, a round-like low-density shadow in front of the pancreas head, approximately 3.3*2.6 cm. Normal morphology, size, and density of the spleen. No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal area.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain and limited movement in the right thumb for one year.

Text.Past Medical History: Hammer deformity of the right little finger for ten years.
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: no heat or redness at the palmar metacarpophalangeal joint of the right thumb, but a soybean-sized hard nodule palpable with tenderness, moving with flexion and extension of the thumb.

 Hammer deformity of the right little finger.  

 No obvious abnormalities in the remaining limbs.  

 Hand X-ray: <\image00008.jpg>.

Text.Chief Complaint: Persistent upper abdominal pain for one day
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports continuous severe pain in the upper abdomen that started one day ago without any apparent cause, radiating to the back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting three times, totaling approximately 800 milliliters of gastric content, without blood or worms. The pain did not alleviate after vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: History of Type 2 diabetes for 2 years, well-controlled with long-term oral medication.
Text.Examinations:
Palpation: Reduced abdominal breathing, slightly distended abdomen, no visible intestinal peristalsis or bowel waves, liver and spleen not palpable beyond the costal margin, generalized abdominal tenderness without rebound pain or muscle guarding, most severe in the upper left quadrant, no costovertebral angle tenderness.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00016.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells at 10.19*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage at 83.30%, lymphocyte percentage at 10.40%, neutrophil count at 8.49*10^9/L. Urinalysis: ketones +3, glucose +4, protein +3. Bicarbonate 12.81 mmol/L, blood sugar 14.44 mmol/L.
Text.Treatment: Exploratory laparotomy, splenectomy

Image.00016.jpg: Normal liver size and shape, decreased liver parenchymal density, no dilation in intrahepatic or extrahepatic bile ducts, normal-sized gallbladder with no obvious stones. Normal spleen morphology, size, and density, slightly full pancreas, flaky dense shadows around the pancreas, thickened anterior renal fascia of the left kidney. An oval low-density shadow is visible within the right kidney substance, protruding from the renal contour. Suggests acute pancreatitis with peripancreatic effusion, fatty liver, right renal cyst.

Text.Chief Complaint: Chronic constipation for 20 years, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, abdominal distension, and cessation of gas and bowel movements for 3 days.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports chronic constipation starting 20 years ago without an apparent cause, with hard stools occurring every 3 to 5 days and difficulty defecating, but without pain unless attempting to defecate, and no bloody or purulent stools. Previously diagnosed locally as 'constipation' and improved with oral laxatives (name and dosage unknown); intermittently medicated over 20 years. Constipation recurred 3 days ago, accompanied by episodic severe pain in the right upper abdomen, no radiation, and accompanied by nausea and vomiting five times of gastric contents, totaling about 1000 milliliters, without blood or worms. Abdominal pain slightly reduced after vomiting, accompanied by abdominal distension and cessation of gas and stool passage.
Text.Past Medical History: 20-year history of constipation.
Text.Examinations:
Upright abdominal plain film: <\image00018.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: white blood cells 9.34*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage 88.60%, lymphocyte percentage 7.50%, neutrophils 8.27*10^9/L, lymphocytes 0.70*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Upon hospital admission, comprehensive tests were performed including continuous gastrointestinal decompression, warm soapy water enema of 800 ml, maintaining fluid and electrolyte and acid-base balance. The patient's underlying condition includes deficiency of yin and body fluids, dry and hard stools, lack of facial radiance, pale lips, and a fine and rough pulse. In traditional Chinese medicine, diagnosed as blood and yin deficiency, treatment should nourish yin and moisten dryness. Administered intestinal moistening pills and modified Shengjiang Chengqi Tang via gastric tube, 150 ml, tube clamped for 2 hours, resulting in substantial bowel movement the next day, symptoms and signs resolved.

Image.00018.jpg: No free gas under the diaphragm, intestinal gas and dilation in the right upper abdomen with a large gas-fluid level visible, no clear positive stone shadows in the path of both kidneys and ureters, both abdominal fat lines are still clear. Indicates right upper abdominal intestinal dilation and gas accumulation, large gas-fluid level visible, correlated clinically.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the upper right abdomen one day after cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports that one month ago, she underwent a 'cholecystectomy and choledocholithotomy' due to 'gallbladder stones and common bile duct stones' at another hospital, with good postoperative recovery. One day ago, she experienced sudden severe continuous pain in the upper right abdomen without a clear cause, which was unbearable and radiated to the right shoulder and back, accompanied by nausea and vomiting of gastric contents without bile or coffee-ground material. The pain did not lessen after vomiting and was accompanied by fever with a body temperature of 37.8°C, no chills, and no jaundice.
Text.Past Medical History: History of gallbladder and common bile duct stones for 6 years, long-term intermittent medication use, underwent cholecystectomy and exploration of the common bile duct one month ago.
Text.Examinations:

  CT: <\image00019.jpg>.  

 Complete blood count: WBC: 5.98*10^9/L, neutrophil percentage: 71.00%, lymphocyte percentage: 22.30%; neutrophil count: 3.97*10^9/L, lymphocyte count: 1.24*10^9/L.
Text.Treatment: Treatment with cefoperazone sodium and sulbactam sodium, and omeprazole injections to inhibit gastric acid secretion; intravenous phenobarbital for spasmolytic and analgesic treatment.

No enlarged lymph nodes in the abdominal and retroperitoneal areas, no fluid in the abdominal cavity.

Text.Chief Complaint: Pain in the chest and abdomen following a vehicle accident 2 hours ago
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports pain in the chest and abdomen that started 2 hours ago following a vehicle accident. The chest pain is localized to the left side, worsens with deep breathing and coughing, accompanied by mild respiratory difficulty, but no hemoptysis. The abdominal pain is a continuous dull ache, localized to the upper left quadrant, without episodic worsening.
Text.Past Medical History: None
Text.Examinations:
Physical examination: Thoracic cage without deformity, no evident redness or swelling on the left chest wall, apparent tenderness on palpation from the 3rd to 12th ribs, positive bone crepitus, positive compression test; abdomen flat, mild tenderness on light pressure in the upper left quadrant, no rebound tenderness or muscle rigidity, mild costovertebral angle tenderness over the left kidney, no tenderness over liver or right kidney area, negative shifting dullness, bowel sounds 4-5 times per minute, no splashing or metallic sounds heard, negative abdominal puncture.  

 Abdominal CT: <\image00024.jpg>.  

 Chest CT: 1. Left-sided pneumohydrothorax, band-like opacities in the lower lobes of both lungs; 2. Small nodules in the right middle and upper lobes; 3. Dilatation of the ascending aorta, aortic wall calcification; 4. Bilateral hilar lymph node calcification; 5. Small amount of effusion in the right thoracic cavity, localized thickening of the right pleura; 6. Fractures of the left 3rd to 12th ribs.
Text.Diagnosis: Blunt trauma to the thoracoabdominal region, abdominal effusion
Text.Treatment: Management includes nil by mouth, fluid replenishment, antibiotics, and nutritional support.

Image.00024.jpg: Irregular contour of the spleen; slightly higher density under the capsule of the left kidney; calcification spot in the right lobe of the liver; thickened gallbladder wall; small amount of abdominal effusion.

Text.Chief Complaint: Episodic headaches for one month, worsening over the past day.
Text.Present Illness: The patient has experienced episodic headaches without any apparent cause for the past month, primarily located in the occipital and vertex regions, characterized by a feeling of pressure. These episodes occur daily, several times a day, each lasting about 10 to 20 minutes with some relief, accompanied by nausea but no vomiting, no limb numbness or weakness, no speech disturbances, and no seizures. Over the past month leading up to admission, symptoms gradually worsened to constant headaches accompanied by nausea and vomiting several times, with vomitus being gastric contents, and slight relief of the headache post-vomiting.
Text.Past Medical History: History of hypertension with poor blood pressure control; history of diabetes with fair glucose control. The patient's neurological examination is normal, with no signs of focal weakness, sensory deficits, or coordination problems. The patient's cardiovascular examination is also normal, with no signs of hypertension or tachycardia.

Diagnosis:

Based on the patient's symptoms and examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). BPPV is a common cause of vertigo and is characterized by brief episodes of dizziness that are triggered by changes in head position. The spinning sensation described by the patient is consistent with the symptoms of BPPV.

Treatment Plan:

The treatment for BPPV typically involves a series of head movements called the Epley maneuver, which can be performed by a healthcare professional. Text.Chief Complaint: Coughing, expectorating phlegm, and chest pain for 2 months, worsening over the last half month.
Text.Present Illness: Two months prior to admission, after catching cold, the patient started experiencing coughing and expectoration, mainly in fits lasting about several minutes that would resolve spontaneously. He produces a small amount of white viscous sputum, accompanied by bilateral chest wall pain, predominantly on the right side, noticeable during deep inhalation and unrelated to physical activity. No chills, fever, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, hoarseness, chest tightness, palpitations, night sweats, hemoptysis, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, aversion to oils, poor appetite, jaundice, or urinary symptoms like frequency, urgency, or pain. No abdominal distension or pain, diarrhea. The patient self-medicated with 'cough medicine' (specific treatment unknown to the patient), but noticed no significant improvement. Symptoms worsened half a month ago, and intermittent self-medication with 'penicillin' did not relieve the symptoms.
Text.Past Medical History: Generally in moderate health, underwent surgery for cervical spondylosis over a year ago with metal implantation. A smoker for 40 years, averaging 20 cigarettes/day, has not quit. Drank alcohol for 40 years, mainly strong spirits, averaging about 250 ml/day, quit 2 years ago.

Blood gas analysis (without oxygen): pH 7.40, bicarbonate 25.4 mmol/L, partial pressure of oxygen 80 mmHg↓, lactate 1.6 mmol/L, partial pressure of carbon dioxide 41 mmHg.

Text.Chief Complaint: Upper abdominal pain accompanied by nausea and vomiting for over 5 hours
Text.Present Illness: The patient reports onset of upper abdominal pain 5 hours ago after consuming chicken legs and chicken soup. The pain, which is episodic and intensifies in bursts, is accompanied by nausea and vomiting of stomach contents. The abdominal pain did not ease after vomiting. There were no loose or bloody stools, no fever, no cough or expectoration, and no chest tightness or chest pain. Symptoms did not improve after self-administration of aluminum magnesium suspension.
Text.Past Medical History: History of rheumatoid arthritis and gout for over 7 years, with intermittent hospital treatments and regular oral pain management with fenbid. Similar episode occurred about 2 months ago, which gradually improved after self-medication with aluminum magnesium suspension and other treatments.
Text.Examinations: Upper abdominal CT: <\image00031.jpg>
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes a third-generation cephalosporin with enzyme inhibitor (cefoperazone-sulbactam) for infection, Xuebijing intravenous drip to regulate immune response and suppress inflammation, tracheal intubation with protective ventilation strategy (from 3.25 to 3.30), continuous enteral lavage and catharsis, external application of magnesium sulfate on the abdomen, and bilateral lower limb movement therapy on a rehabilitation bicycle to promote intestinal motility. Antibiotics adjusted to meropenem in combination with vancomycin.

Image.00031.jpg: Changes around the head of the pancreas, suggesting the possibility of pancreatitis.

检查报告: Upper abdominal CT: <\image00031.jpg>

Antibiotics adjusted to meropenem in combination with vancomycin.

The patient's symptoms are consistent with food poisoning, which can be caused by a viral or bacterial infection or consuming undercooked or contaminated food.

The patient is advised to stop taking the aluminum magnesium suspension and focus on staying hydrated. Text.Chief Complaint: Presenting to our hospital due to 'fever and headache for 7 days'.
Text.Present Illness: The patient started experiencing fever 7 days ago, with temperatures reaching up to 37.5°C, and headaches affecting the entire head, occurring intermittently and lasting about 30 minutes each. The headaches, sometimes unbearable, did not respond well to oral pain medication occasionally and did not show a clear correlation with body position. Headaches occurred even when her temperature was normal.
Text.Past Medical History: 45 days ago, the patient had a fever peaking at 39°C with chills, tested positive for the novel coronavirus, followed by a decrease in temperature. 15 days ago, she again developed a fever reaching 38°C, with no cough or expectoration, testing positive for coronavirus antigen. Intermittently took ibuprofen. Denies any history of diabetes, kidney diseases, surgeries, trauma, blood transfusions, and has been vaccinated against COVID-19.
Text.Examinations:
Cranial CT: <\image00032.jpg>.  

 First lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 300 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 420×10^6/L, red blood cells 140×10^6/L, white blood cells 280×10^6/L, 80% polymorphonuclear cells, 20% mononuclear cells.  

 CSF biochemistry: Protein 0.64 g/L, glucose 2.0 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 8.4 mmol/L), lactate 2.4 mmol/L. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus.  

 Second lumbar puncture cerebrospinal fluid: Pressure 150 mmH2O, clear appearance, total cell count 190×10^6/L, red blood cells 90×10^6/L, white blood cells 100×10^6/L, 64% polymorphonuclear cells, 36% mononuclear cells. Biochemistry: Protein 0.34 g/L, glucose 2.4 mmol/L (blood glucose at the same time 5.2 mmol/L), lactate 1.8 mmol/L. Adenosine deaminase in CSF 2.4 U/L, in blood 24 U/L. No bacteria seen on Gram stain, no acid-fast bacilli on acid-fast stain. India ink staining did not reveal cryptococcus. CSF culture showed no bacterial growth. Tuberculosis infection T-cell test negative.  

 CSF cytology: Abnormal, predominantly lymphocytic.
Text.Treatment: Treatment includes doxycycline 100mg twice daily for 5 months, rifampin 0.6g twice daily for 5 months, and ceftriaxone 2g twice daily intravenously for infection control and symptomatic treatment.
